abstract: The frustration that Billy Beane felt when listening to his scouts talking about baseball players is the frustration that a political scientist feels when listening to many campaign consultants, journalists, and political commentators talk about political advertising.

lead_paragraph: Readers of the book "Moneyball" will know the type. Grizzled advisers, veterans of many past contests, sit around the table. They can size up any prospect. They can immediately intuit that person's strengths and weaknesses. They know what works, because they have done this so many times. They have stories of what happened 2 years ago or 4 years ago or 16 years ago. They remember the key moments -- the crucial plays, the turning points. They know what it takes to win the championship.
